Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of male youth with large bulging eyes and toothy smile. Head only. Crudely made. Hand-made (?) and solid with crude back. Traces of red paint or slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric with grey core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

'116' or '118' written on the back in pencil, probably Gutch's number (in Hogarth 1899, 84, nos 116-118) that identifies this as coming from Hogarth's Site 38. Similar Late Period parallels have been dated 5th to 4th century BC (Fischer 1994, pl.1, no.3 and pl.4, no.23; Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl.98.1, no.560 and particularly pl.97.3 and 5, nos 552-554) and pieces in a similar style have been found at Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl.37, no.22 and pl. 35, nos 3 and 15). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1909a, Memphis I. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.307) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 84, nos 116 or 118)
